Graphical abstract The clean transformation of coal into natural gas is an interesting topic in green chemistry, as well as a promising process for the production of natural gas. In the present work, the methanation of CO was performed in a slurry-bed reactor with a series of nanosized Ni–Al2O3 catalysts prepared by microwave-assisted solution combustion with different fuels (urea, glycine, ethylene glycol and citric acid). As compared with other fuels, a majority of urea and nitrates simultaneously decompose and occur in extensive overlapped temperature ranges during heating, which is conducive to the formation of a moderate and sustained combustion reaction. In addition, the thermodynamic calculation and thermogravimetric analysis indicate that the amount of heat generated during combustion is the minimum when urea was used as fuel. By the formation of a stable combustion and a relative low combustion temperature, the NiAl-U catalyst exhibits the largest BET area and metal surface area, the smallest Ni particle size and more dispersive Ni species, as evidenced by XRD, TEM, N2 adsorption–desorption, H2-TPR and H2 pulse chemisorption characterizations. In the slurry methanation of CO, the conversion of CO and selectivity for CH4 over NiAl-U catalyst reach up to 95.7% and 96.2% at 300°C, 1.0MPa and 3000mL/gcat h, respectively, which are superior to those of other combustion-synthesized catalysts and commercial catalyst. In addition, The NiAl-U catalyst exhibits significant improvement in anti-sintering during 200h lifetime test, mainly because of smaller Ni particle size, high dispersity of Ni active species on support and high stability of support. The findings presented here are expected to provide new approaches for rational design of nanosized Ni–Al2O3 catalysts for CO methanation reactions in slurry phase. Keywords Slurry-bed reactor CO methanation Synthetic natural gas Ni–Al2O3 catalyst Microwave-assisted solution combustion 1 Introduction In the last decade, significant amounts of coal have been consumed, and environmental pollution has become increasingly serious in China. In 2014, the total energy consumption in China has surpassed 4 billion tons of standard coal, where coal consumption accounts to greater than 70% and constitutes more than 50% of the global total of coal consumption [1]. In recent years, most areas of China often experience severe air pollution such as fog and hazy weather, significantly caused by the burning of coal. Meanwhile, coal to synthetic natural gas (SNG) via coal gasification, gas conditioning, gas cleaning, and methanation is considered to be a vital technology for the clean and efficient utilization of coal in China [1–4]. Among the processes for SNG production, CO hydrogenated to SNG is a core step and a highly exothermic reaction (3H2 +CO→CH4 +H2O; ΔH293K =−206kJ/mol) [5]. Thus, in the methanation process, the one of the major challenge is to remove the enormous heat produced by the reaction. To date, fixed-bed methanation technology, which involves the use of two to four fixed-bed reactors connected in series for the cooling or recycling of feed gas, has been universally employed for the commercial production of SNG. In the first stage of fixed-bed methanation, the reaction temperature is controlled at 500–700°C to accelerate the reaction rate, and in the final stage, the reaction temperature is controlled to 320°C to obtain a high yield of SNG. However, the catalyst bed is easily overheated regionally, caused by the high exothermic reaction heat and the poor heat transfer in the fixed-bed reactor, thereby causing catalyst deactivation by carbon deposition as well as catalyst sintering [2,6–8]. In a slurry-bed reactor, it is well known that catalyst particles are uniformly suspended in an inert solvent. Thus, the large amount of heat produced by the reaction can instantly dissipate to the surroundings so that the catalyst bed can be operated almost isothermally and as low as 320°C, thereby enhancing the yield of methane, and prolonging the lifetime of the catalyst. Nowadays, slurry-bed reactors are widely employed for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, methanol synthesis, methanol dehydrogenation and hydrogenation [9–12]. Despite these advantages, the use of slurry-bed reactors for methanation has been less investigated thus far. Typically, nickel-based catalysts are widely used for fixed-bed methanation [6,13–16]. However, they do not exhibit high activities and stabilities for CO methanation in the slurry-bed reactor at low temperature [2]. Recently, Zhang et al. [17] prepared a Zr-doped 25% Ni 3% Zr/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by impregnation co-precipitation, and it exhibited a high CO conversion of 91.2% and CH4 selectivity of 85.2% at 325°C for CO methanation in a slurry-bed reactor. Meng et al. [18] found that a Ni–Ce/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by the coimpregnation of Ni and Ce exhibited higher activity for the catalytic methanation of CO as compared to that exhibited by the Ni–Al2O3 catalyst with a CO conversion of 95.4% and CH4 selectivity of 90.7% at 280°C. Ni-based catalysts have been intensively investigated by impregnation [19], co-precipitation [20], the fusion method [21], the solution-spray plasma technique [22] and sol-gel [23]. Recently, a novel one-step solution combustion technology has been employed for the preparation of nanomaterials and nanosized supported metal catalysts and has attracted significant attention. It involves the heating of an aqueous solution of metal nitrates and organic fuels to the ignition temperature followed by the spontaneous combustion of the mixed solution [24–28]. Due to the initial reaction media is liquid state where metal salt and fuel molecules mixing on the molecular level, thus permitting precise and homogeneous formulation of the desired composition on the nanoscale [29–31]. Kingsley and Patil [32] were the first to prepare fine-particle α-Al2O3 material by the combustion of a solution of aluminum nitrate and urea. Zhao et al. [33] prepared the 20% Ni–Al2O3 catalyst by the solution combustion method, and found this catalyst exhibited higher catalytic activity than that of an impregnated catalyst. The traditional solution combustion synthesis was conducted by electrical heating such as muffle oven [34], hot plate [35] and heating mantle [36]. As a result, the material thus prepared exhibits regional inhomogeneity, caused by an inevitable steep thermal gradient between the interior and exterior of the heated solution. In contrast, under microwave irradiation, the solution mixture is homogeneously heated, thereby forming a uniform catalyst that exhibits superior catalytic activity [37–41]. Tahmasebi and Paydar [38] have reported that a nanocomposite powder material of alumina with 20wt% zirconia prepared by solution combustion in a microwave furnace consists of finer particles (<20nm) with a narrower size distribution and better homogeneity of zirconia particles in an alumina matrix as compared to that prepared in a traditional heating furnace. Esmaeili et al. [41] have prepared 4.1nm MgO nanoparticles with a specific surface area of 400m2/g from magnesium nitrate and polyethylene glycol or sorbitol as the fuel by solution combustion under microwave irradiation. Encouraged by previous studies, first, a series of Ni–Al2O3 catalysts containing highly dispersed nanosized Ni particles were prepared by microwave-assisted solution combustion; to the best of the authors’ knowledge, there have been no reports of this type of Ni–Al2O3 catalyst preparation. Next, the influence of fuel on combustion behavior, as well as the correlation of physicochemical properties of the catalysts and the intrinsic methanation activity, were investigated and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation First, 29.43g (0.078mol) aluminum nitrate nonahydrate Al(NO3)3∙9H2O (Guangfu Fine Chemical Institute research Co., Ltd., China, AR grade) and 4.95g (0.017mol) nickel nitrate hexahydrate Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China, AR grade) were completely dissolved in a minimum volume of deionized water in a 100mL beaker, then the desired amount of fuel such as urea, glycine, ethylene glycol and citric acid (Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China, AR grade) was added into the solution and dissolved completely. The mixture solution was stirred vigorously and kept at 60°C for 1h, then transferred to a crucible and heated in a microwave oven at 2.45GHz and 700W. During the microwave heating process, the solution was heated to boil and froth, and converted to gel. Then the gel ignited spontaneously and rapidly with the release of a large amount of gases, yielding fluffy and porous powder. The overall combustion process is less than 60s. The powder was further heated at 400°C for 1h in a muffle oven to stabilize the material structure and remove the undecomposed reactants. The Ni–Al2O3 catalysts with 20wt% metallic Ni loading prepared by urea, glycine, ethylene glycol and citric acid were denoted as NiAl-U, NiAl-G, NiAl-E and NiAl-C, respectively. In all cases, the stoichiometric molar ratio of fuel to oxidant was chosen and calculated according to Jain et al.’s propellant theory [42]. For comparison, the commercial methanation catalyst 18% NiO-6% TiO2-4% MnO2/Al2O3 (named J108-2Q from Sichuan Shutai Chemical Technology Co., Ltd., China) was used as a reference catalyst and termed as J108-2Q. Nevertheless, when a different fuel is used, the combustion phenomenon is quite different, as listed in Table 1 . In case of the NiAl-U catalyst, a bright flame is observed. In fact, the theoretical calculations were based on a hypothesis that the system is adiabatic, and the combustion is complete. For gaining insight into the formation of the materials, the thermo-analysis is necessary to understand the details of the thermal process. Guo et al. [44] adopt this method to simulate the combustion process, and get available information of mass loss and thermal decomposition. By carrying out simultaneous DTG-DTA measurements, the chemical reactions occurring during the combustion process were understood better, and the information of the thermal decomposition and variation of heat were more accurate and reliable. In order to better understand the intrinsic nature of combustion process, the behaviors on heating of each single reagent as well as that of dried gels, made by combining urea with metal nitrates were studied by differential thermal gravimetry (DTG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA), as shown in Fig. 1 a and b. The decomposition of Ni(NO3)2 clearly proceeds in two temperature stages—210–270°C and 270–340°C—and is accompanied by two endothermic peaks at 213 and 323°C, respectively, in the DTA graph. On the other hand, the thermal dissociation of Al(NO3)3 occurs in a wide temperature range within 80–190°C, and two corresponding endothermic peaks at 75 and 155°C, respectively, are observed in DTA. Moreover, the thermal decomposition of urea occurs at two extensive temperatures—120–230°C and 280–400°C—during which the DTA curve exhibits three endothermic peaks around 136, 240, and 384°C. Meanwhile, the decomposition of glycine occurs in two stages. The first step is the main process of mass loss at 230–290°C, followed by a slight weight loss at 504–630°C. Accordingly, in the DTA graph of glycine, an endothermic peak at 254°C and a broad exothermic peak around 541°C are observed. Notably, the decomposition of ethylene glycol is practically a one-stage process at 130–230°C, associated with one endothermic peak observed at 206°C in the DTA curve. In the DTG curve of citric acid, a sharp mass loss peak at 150–220°C and a marginal weight loss peak around 483°C are observed; their corresponding peaks in the DTA graph show two continuous endothermic peaks at 157 and 212°C, as well as an exothermic peak at 512°C. With respect to the thermal decomposition of fuel–nitrate gels, the DTG profile of urea–nitrate gel exhibits a mass loss peak at around 150°C, attributed to the dehydration of gel and decomposition of Al(NO3)3. The next three mass loss peaks occur at 215–246°C, 246–285°C, and 321–358°C, respectively, which are attributed to the thermal decomposition of urea and Ni(NO3)2. In the DTA diagram, the urea–nitrate gel exhibits three weak exothermic peaks at 156, 245, and 330°C, respectively, which are located in the overlapped decomposition temperature regions of urea and nitrates. Therefore, these continuous exothermic effects are attributed to a series of simultaneous chemical reactions i.e., the decomposition of urea and nitrates, as well as the combustion between the decomposition products. Moreover, in the DTG graph of glycine–nitrate, ethylene glycol–nitrate, and citric acid–nitrate gels, weight loss is observed to varying degrees between 140 and 170°C. These three gels exhibit one sharp weight loss peak around 210, 162, and 172°C, respectively, attributed to the dissociation of nitrates and fuels. The second weight loss peak at 368 and 382°C in the ethylene glycol–nitrate and citric acid–nitrate gels is attributed to the decomposition of residual samples. Accordingly, these three gels show one abrupt exothermic peak at 213, 164, and 175°C, attributed to the combustion of fuel and nitrates. Afterwards, in the DTA of ethylene glycol–nitrate and citric acid–nitrate gels, the other exothermic peak belongs to the combustion of residual reactants. As mentioned above, the thermal decomposition of the urea and nitrates occurs at three overlapped temperature intervals—120–190, 210–230, and 280–340°C, respectively; thus, a stepwise and sustained combustion could occur between 120 and 340°C, which is conducive to the heat dissipation; the agglomeration of the Ni particles could be prevented to a large extent. On the other hand, the overlapped temperature ranges for other fuel and nitrates are in one limited temperature range, thus resulting in a smolder and instant combustion reaction; the instantaneous release of large heat could result in regional overheat, which in turn leads to sintering of the Ni particles. Thus, the nature of combustion process was clarified by investigating the thermal decomposition of nitrates and fuels, and the results obtained from DTA are in good agreement with theoretical calculations, where exothermicity is the smallest when urea is used as the fuel. 3.2 Textural and structural properties Table 2 lists the textural and structural properties of calcined and reduced catalysts. The Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) surface area of the calcined catalysts with different fuels used varies from 13.8m2/g to 256.2m2/g; the NiAl-U catalyst exhibits the highest SBET. After reduction, the SBET of the NiAl-U catalyst decreases to 186.1m2/g, while the SBET of NiAl-G and NiAl-E catalysts increases from 23.2m2/g to 60.4m2/g and 15.5m2/g to 17.1m2/g, respectively; moreover, the SBET of the NiAl-C catalyst decreases slightly. Notably, the average pore diameter clearly increases after reduction for all catalysts except the NiAl-U catalyst. It is proposed that the reduction process at 550°C for 6h would causing collapse in pore structure as well as growth and aggregation of particles that diminish the BET surface area. At the same time, the residual fuels and nitrates in pore or surface decompose at high temperature that part of the surface was exposed, resulting in an increase of the BET surface area. As depicted in DTG curves (Fig. 1a), a tiny amount of glycine residue decomposes around 563°C, which is not occurred in other fuels. Thus, the decomposition of residual glycine exerts a main effect on the increase of BET surface area. Nevertheless, in the case of NiAl-U, a stepwise and sustained combustion lead to a nearly complete reaction of urea, the collapse of pore structure as well as growth and aggregation of particles during reduction process exerts a great influence on the decrease of BET surface area. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the quantitative changes of BET surface area are depended on the balance of the two effects. To quantify the change of Ni surface area and metal dispersion, H2 pulse chemisorption technology was employed. The NiAl-U catalyst exhibits the maximum Ni metal surface area of 34.6m2/g, while the NiAl-C catalyst exhibits the minimum Ni metal surface area of 1.8m2/g. The same situation is observed for the evolution of metal dispersion. These results confirmed that a large combustion enthalpy leads to agglomeration and sintering of Ni particles, which result in decrease in the SBET and Ni surface area. 3.3. Evolution of crystalline phase Fig. 2 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the calcined and reduced catalysts prepared by solution combustion using different fuels. The calcined NiAl-G catalyst exhibits diffraction peaks of NiO (JCPDS card No. 47-1049) at 2θ =37.3°, 62.9°, 75.3° and 79.4°, γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS card No. 10-0425) at 2θ =37.6°, 45.9° and 67.3° as well as weak diffraction peaks of Ni (JCPDS card No. 04-0850) at 2θ =44.5°, 51.8° and 76.3°, indicating that NiO and metallic Ni are the main Ni species present in the NiAl-G catalyst; the formation of these species indicate that NiO is partially reduced to metallic Ni during combustion. The NiAl-U catalyst exhibits diffraction peaks at 2θ of 37.6°, 45.9°, and 67.3°, attributed to γ-Al2O3, without any obvious diffraction peaks of the Ni species. Moreover, the NiAl-G catalyst displays strong intensity diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 as compared to those of the NiAl-U catalyst, indicating that the NiAl-G catalyst has a better crystallinity and larger particle sizes. Remarkably, the XRD patterns do not contain diffraction peaks corresponding to Ni, NiO, or γ-Al2O3 in the prepared NiAl-E and NiAl-C catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2b, for the reduced Ni–Al2O3 catalysts, all combustion-synthesized catalysts exhibit characteristic diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.3°, attributed to the Ni metal, and also, peaks corresponding to NiO were not observed in the XRD patterns, indicating that NiO is predominantly reduced to metallic Ni after reduction at 550°C for 6h. As compared to the other catalysts, the NiAl-G catalysts show stronger characteristic peaks of γ-Al2O3. The weak, broad diffraction peaks of Ni and γ-Al2O3 exhibited by the NiAl-U catalyst indicate that aggregated particles are not formed, and the Ni active species are highly dispersed over the γ-Al2O3 support surface. However, the NiAl-E and NiAl-C catalysts do not exhibit crystalline phases attributed to γ-Al2O3. The crystallite sizes of Ni were estimated from XRD patterns at 2θ =51.8° (plane of 200) applying the Scherrer equation; they are summarized in Table 2. The NiAl-U catalyst has the smallest Ni particle size of 9.2nm, while the NiAl-C has the largest Ni particle size of 18.8nm. The results demonstrated that large combustion heat leads to a high combustion temperature, resulting in the coarsening and agglomeration of the particles. Also, it is known that a large quantity of gases evolved during combustion dissipates the heat and restrains interparticle agglomeration and particle growth of the prepared materials [31]. 3.3 Morphology of calcined catalysts Fig. 3 shows the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of the calcined Ni–Al2O3 catalysts. Clear distinctions are observed for catalysts prepared using different fuels, and all catalysts exhibit NiO particles with sizes ranging from 4 to 20nm. As shown in Fig. 3a, the 4–7nm NiO particles are uniformly dispersed on the Al2O3 surface, without any agglomeration of the NiAl-U catalyst. A relatively larger NiO particle size (5–9nm) and scarce agglomeration are observed in the NiAl-G catalyst (Fig. 3b). The size of the NiO particles in the NiAl-E catalyst (Fig. 3c) is 5–13nm with regional agglomeration. The NiAl-C catalyst exhibits apparent agglomeration, and the NiO particle size is 10–22nm and significantly greater than that in other catalysts (Fig. 3d). It is evident to observe in these micrographs that the interaction between NiO particles and support is quite different. For NiAl-U and NiAl-E catalysts, the NiO particles are distributed on the surface of the Al2O3 support, while the NiO particles are partially “dissolved” in the support for NiAl-G and NiAl-C catalysts. The results obtained from HRTEM analysis are consistent with those obtained from XRD characterization, where the particle size of NiAl-U catalyst is the smallest, while that of the NiAl-C catalyst is the largest (Fig. 2). 3.4 Reducibility of catalysts Fig. 4 shows the results of the H2-TPR experiments, which were conducted for investigating the reducibility and amount of reducible NiO species of the combustion-synthesized Ni–Al2O3 catalysts. As shown in the graph, the NiAl-U catalyst exhibit two individual reduction peaks at 301 and 464°C; the NiAl-G catalyst exhibit a broad band of H2 consumption in the range of 150–887°C; the NiAl-E catalyst exhibit a small peak at 376°C and a broad peak in the range of 438–855°C; the NiAl-C catalyst show two individual peaks at 396 and 570°C, and a tiny reduction peak at 806°C. Due to the Al2O3 is not reduced within the temperature range of 100–900°C, the reduction peaks are attributed to the reducible NiO species. The overlapped peaks of H2-TPR patterns are fitted by the Gaussian function and classified into four peaks—α, β1, β2, and γ. The peak positions and the quantitative results of H2 consumption are listed in Table 3 . The low-temperature peaks are assigned to amorphous NiO species and denoted as type α. The medium-temperature peaks represent the β-type NiO species, which possess a stronger interaction with Al2O3 than α-type NiO, and can be further divided into mixed oxides: β1-type oxide in the Ni-rich phase and the less reducible β2-type oxide in the Al-rich phase [45,46]. As well known, the metal Ni resulting from the reduction of β-type NiO is the major active center in the methanation of CO [17,47]. The high-temperature γ-type peaks are attributed to NiAl2O4 with a spinel structure [48,49]. Obviously, nickel oxide species in NiAl-U catalyst are mostly reduced at much lower temperature compared to that of other catalysts. These results indicate that the use of urea can promote the dispersion of NiO and enhance the reducibility of NiO, a fact that is consistent with H2 pulse chemisorption and HRTEM results. As shown in Table 3, β-type NiO is the major NiO species in all the NiAl catalysts. The H2 consumption of the β-type reduction peak for the NiAl-U, NiAl-G, NiAl-E and NiAl-C catalysts is 2.99, 2.70, 2.18mmol/g and 1.36mmol/g, respectively, which implies more amount of metallic Ni is exposed after reduction for NiAl-U. In addition, as compared to other NiAl catalysts, a reduction peak attributed to the γ-type NiO for the NiAl-U catalyst is not observed, which means a weaker interaction between NiO and Al2O3 support and a higher utilization of Ni species by inhibiting the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel phase. The result indicates that the amount of easily reducible and highly dispersed nickel oxide are generated when urea was used as the fuel on account of the low temperature and large amount of gases during combustion, which is conducive to the restriction of particle agglomeration as well as the formation of a moderate interaction between NiO and Al2O3 support. In addition, the reduction degree of the catalysts was calculated using TPR data, the results confirmed when urea was used as fuel, more metallic nickel could be formed after reduction which turns out to be more active sites, which is in good agreement with the results of H2 pulse chemisorption. 3.5 Catalytic activity and stability The slurry methanation of CO was conducted over the combustion-synthesized Ni–Al2O3 catalysts and J108-2Q at 220–300°C, 1.0MPa, and a space velocity of 3000mL/gcat h and is shown in Fig. 5 . It was detected in the process of CO methanation that the products are composed of CO, H2, CH4, CO2, H2O, and C2–4 gases (including C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, C3H8, C4H8 and C4H10). And the calculated thermodynamic equilibrium data are also shown in Fig. 5. As shown in Fig. 5a, in case of all combustion-synthesized Ni–Al2O3 catalysts, i.e., NiAl-U, NiAl-G, NiAl-E, and NiAl-C, in which urea, glycine, ethylene glycol, and citric acid were used as fuels in the preparation, CO conversion increases gradually with increasing temperature from 220 to 300°C (Fig. 5a). Among the four prepared catalysts, the CO conversion over the NiAl-U catalyst at 220°C is 62.6%; however, for the others, CO conversion is less than 7.0%. When the reaction temperature increases from 240 to 300°C, the CO conversion over the NiAl-U catalyst gradually increases to 95.8% that is very close to the thermodynamics equilibrium data at 300°C, while that over other catalysts evidently increases, but the values are less than 90.6%. For the commercial catalyst J108-2Q, the CO conversion increases gradually with increasing temperature; however, it is still significantly lower than that of the NiAl-U catalyst in the whole temperature range tested. As shown in Fig. 5b and c, the selectivities of all catalysts for CH4 increase as the temperature increases from 220 to 300°C, while the catalysts exhibit an opposite trend for the selectivity for C2–4. The NiAl-U catalyst exhibits a higher selectivity for CH4 that nearly reaches the thermodynamics equilibrium when the temperature is as high as 300°C, and a lower selectivity for C2–4 as compared to those of other catalysts. Meanwhile, the catalyst show a distinct difference in the selectivity for CO2 (Fig. 5d). For the NiAl-U catalyst, the selectivity for CO2 decreases from 10.7% to 3.2% with the increase in temperature from 240 to 300°C; however, for the other catalysts, it increases. This result implies that the NiAl-U catalyst produces less CO2 at high temperature. To investigate the stability of the catalysts, slurry methanation of CO was conducted at 300°C, 1.0MPa, and 3000mL/gcat h for 200h. As shown in Fig. 6 a, with the increase in time–on–stream, deactivation is not observed for the CO conversion over the NiAl-U catalyst in 200h, while the CO conversion over the NiAl-G, NiAl-E, and NiAl-C catalysts rapidly decreases from 92.2, 78.0, and 65.9% to 74.5, 55.1, and 41.1%, respectively. However, the selectivity for CH4 in all the catalysts kept stable during the test period. In order to further check the stability of the NiAl-U catalyst far from the thermodynamic equilibrium, the test results at lower reaction temperature of 260°C and higher space velocity of 8000mL/gcat h for 300h are shown in the Fig 6c. As presents, with the increase of time-on-stream, the activity of the catalyst NiAl-U is still stable within 300h at low temperature 260°C and high space velocity 8000mL/gca h. These results are more proof of the high stability of the NiAl-U catalyst. The active metal surface area and metal dispersion are well known to reflect the surface properties of catalysts, which directly correlate to catalytic activity. First, a large Ni surface area implies abundant Ni active sites, which enhance the adsorption capacity of CO and H2 and promote the dissociation of CO caused by a lower apparent activation energy for CO dissociation, thereby leading to a higher methanation activity [50,51]. Furthermore, favorable metal dispersion leads to the formation of small Ni particles and restrains the aggregation of particles. Therefore, the variation trend of catalytic activity is easy to understand by considering the similar trend of the Ni surface area. However, the activity at low temperature is worth discussing. As discussed above, the catalytic activity at high temperature follows the Ni surface area. Yet the catalytic activity at low temperature is depended on many factors, such as Ni surface area, reduction degree and the amount of α-NiO and β-NiO. As Fig. 5a presents, the CO conversion of NiAl-E is higher than that of the NiAl-G at 240°C, except the measured value of the reduction degree is close in the two sample, the amount of α-NiO largely affects the low-temperature activity. Previous studies [51,52] found that metal Ni resulting from the reduction of amorphous NiO displays high catalytic activity in the methanation of CO. However, this type of Ni is easy to aggregate that resulting in growth and sintering of Ni crystallite. It is assumed that the aggregation of Ni resulting from amorphous NiO at low temperature was not as severe as at high temperature, thus its contribution to catalytic activity was increased. Even though the amount of α-NiO in NiAl-C is large, its Ni crystallite size is much larger than that of other catalysts. It is still easy to aggregate to result in a low activity. The used catalysts NiAl-U* and NiAl-C* after a stability test at 300°C, 1.0MPa, and 3000mL/gcat h, were further characterized by TEM, XRD and TG-DTG characterizations. TEM image of the used NiAl-U* catalyst is shown in Fig. 7 a, the morphology remains unchanged and there is no observation of carbon filament on the surface of the catalysts with high dispersion of Ni particles. The particle size of Ni increases slightly, compared to the fresh catalyst. However, for the used NiAl-C* catalysts (Fig. 7b), the variation of microstructure can be clearly observed as well as severe aggregation of Ni particles on the Al2O3 support, and some Ni particles above 20nm in size can also be identified, indicating occurrence of sintering of Ni particles during the CO methanation. Notably, there is no filamentous carbon deposition in used NiAl-C* catalysts. At the same time, the XRD patterns of the spent NiAl-U* catalyst in Fig. 7c shows that the diffraction peaks of Ni and γ-Al2O3 are becoming sharper, implying a minor growth of crystallites. With respect to the used NiAl-C* catalyst, there is no significant diffraction peaks attributed to the metallic Ni and γ-Al2O3, indicating that the amount of Ni is below the detection limit of XRD or the nickel is amorphous. However, strong peaks correspond to Al(OH)3 (bayerite, JCPDS card No. 83-2256) are observed. Thus, we speculate that the structural instability and phase transition has exacerbated the aggregation of Ni particles during CO methanation in slurry phase. It is worth noting that there are no diffraction peaks belonged to carbon are observed for both samples, which is in good agreement with the TEM characterization. Furthermore, the used catalysts NiAl-U* and NiAl-C* were analyzed by TG-DTG to check the carbon deposition. As the Fig. 7d shows, all the samples undergone weight loss below 200°C, belonged to the dehydration and desorption of volatile component. A further weight increase around 300°C is attributable to the oxidation of the surface metallic Ni of the used catalysts. Thereafter, mass loss was not observed in the NiAl-U*, indicating the absence of carbon species. Meanwhile, the NiAl-C* sample showed two extensive mass loss at around 260 and 410°C, which might attribute to a series of crystal transition of bayerite support during heating treatment. Therefore, it is reasonable concluded that the NiAl-U catalyst exhibits superior anti-coking and anti-sintering properties during CO methanation. 4 Conclusions A series of nanosized Ni–Al2O3 catalyst by microwave−assisted solution combustion were successfully prepared. Among the four fuels used, i.e., urea, glycine, ethylene glycol and citric acid, combustion generated the minimum amount of heat and released the largest quantity of gases when urea was used as the fuel. Meanwhile, due to a majority of urea, Ni(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3 thermally decompose simultaneously and occur in extensive overlapped temperature intervals during heating, a moderate and sustained combustion reaction is initiated, which is conducive to the heat dissipation. As a result, the NiAl-U catalyst exhibited the smallest size of Ni particles of 9.2nm; the BET area and Ni surface area reach up to 256.2m2/g and 34.6m2/g, respectively, and more easily reducible and highly dispersive Ni species were formed. In the slurry methanation of CO, the sequence of catalytic activity is in good agreement with the results of physicochemical properties, and the CO conversion and selectivity of CH4 over the NiAl-U catalyst reach up to 95.7% and 96.2%, respectively, at 300°C; moreover, it does not exhibit deactivation within 200h, which is superior to the properties of other combustion-synthesized Ni–Al2O3 catalyst and commercial catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The clean transformation of coal into natural gas is an interesting topic in green chemistry, as well as a promising process for the production of natural gas. In the present work, the methanation of CO was performed in a slurry-bed reactor with a series of nanosized Ni–Al2O3 catalysts prepared by microwave-assisted solution combustion with different fuels (urea, glycine, ethylene glycol and citric acid). As compared with other fuels, a majority of urea and nitrates simultaneously decompose and occur in extensive overlapped temperature ranges during heating, which is conducive to the formation of a moderate and sustained combustion reaction. In addition, the thermodynamic calculation and thermogravimetric analysis indicate that the amount of heat generated during combustion is the minimum when urea was used as fuel. By the formation of a stable combustion and a relative low combustion temperature, the NiAl-U catalyst exhibits the largest BET area and metal surface area, the smallest Ni particle size and more dispersive Ni species, as evidenced by XRD, TEM, N2 adsorption–desorption, H2-TPR and H2 pulse chemisorption characterizations. In the slurry methanation of CO, the conversion of CO and selectivity for CH4 over NiAl-U catalyst reach up to 95.7% and 96.2% at 300°C, 1.0MPa and 3000mL/gcat h, respectively, which are superior to those of other combustion-synthesized catalysts and commercial catalyst. In addition, The NiAl-U catalyst exhibits significant improvement in anti-sintering during 200h lifetime test, mainly because of smaller Ni particle size, high dispersity of Ni active species on support and high stability of support. The findings presented here are expected to provide new approaches for rational design of nanosized Ni–Al2O3 catalysts for CO methanation reactions in slurry phase.
